segment.source: Use depth and effects on primitives
segment.target: Use depth and effects on primitives

segment.source: Here, we show you how to use depth, perspective, color, and other effects on primitives.
segment.target: Here, we show you how to use depth, perspective, color, and other effects on primitives.

segment.source: Use depth and effects on primitives
segment.target: Use depth and effects on primitives

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Here, we show you how to use depth, perspective, color, and other effects on primitives.
segment.target: Here, we show you how to use depth, perspective, color, and other effects on primitives.

segment.source: Objective: To create a 3D object and apply basic vertex lighting and coloring to it.
segment.target: Objective: To create a 3D object and apply basic vertex lighting and coloring to it.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: We assume that you are familiar with C++.
segment.target: We assume that you are familiar with C++.

segment.source: You also need basic experience with graphics programming concepts.
segment.target: You also need basic experience with graphics programming concepts.

segment.source: We also assume that you went through Quickstart: setting up DirectX resources and displaying an image and Creating shaders and drawing primitives.
segment.target: We also assume that you went through Quickstart: setting up DirectX resources and displaying an image and Creating shaders and drawing primitives.

segment.source: Time to complete: 20 minutes.
segment.target: Time to complete: 20 minutes.

segment.source: Instructions
segment.target: Instructions

segment.source: 1. Defining cube variables
segment.target: 1. Defining cube variables

segment.source: First, we need to define the SimpleCubeVertex and ConstantBuffer structures for the cube.
segment.target: First, we need to define the SimpleCubeVertex and ConstantBuffer structures for the cube.

segment.source: These structures specify the vertex positions and colors for the cube and how the cube will be viewed.
segment.target: These structures specify the vertex positions and colors for the cube and how the cube will be viewed.

segment.source: We declare ID3D11DepthStencilView and ID3D11Buffer with ComPtr and declare an instance of ConstantBuffer.
segment.target: We declare ID3D11DepthStencilView and ID3D11Buffer with ComPtr and declare an instance of ConstantBuffer.

segment.source: 2. Creating a depth stencil view
segment.target: 2. Creating a depth stencil view

segment.source: In addition to creating the render-target view, we also create a depth-stencil view.
segment.target: In addition to creating the render-target view, we also create a depth-stencil view.

segment.source: The depth-stencil view enables Direct3D to efficiently render objects closer to the camera in front of objects further from the camera.
segment.target: The depth-stencil view enables Direct3D to efficiently render objects closer to the camera in front of objects further from the camera.

segment.source: Before we can create a view to a depth-stencil buffer, we must create the depth-stencil buffer.
segment.target: Before we can create a view to a depth-stencil buffer, we must create the depth-stencil buffer.

segment.source: We populate a D3D11\_TEXTURE2D\_DESC to describe the depth-stencil buffer and then call ID3D11Device::CreateTexture2D to create the depth-stencil buffer.
segment.target: We populate a D3D11\_TEXTURE2D\_DESC to describe the depth-stencil buffer and then call ID3D11Device::CreateTexture2D to create the depth-stencil buffer.

segment.source: To create the depth-stencil view, we populate a D3D11\_DEPTH\_STENCIL\_VIEW\_DESC to describe the depth-stencil view and pass the depth-stencil view description and the depth-stencil buffer to ID3D11Device::CreateDepthStencilView.
segment.target: To create the depth-stencil view, we populate a D3D11\_DEPTH\_STENCIL\_VIEW\_DESC to describe the depth-stencil view and pass the depth-stencil view description and the depth-stencil buffer to ID3D11Device::CreateDepthStencilView.

segment.source: 3. Updating perspective with the window
segment.target: 3. Updating perspective with the window

segment.source: We update the perspective projection parameters for the constant buffer depending on the window dimensions.
segment.target: We update the perspective projection parameters for the constant buffer depending on the window dimensions.

segment.source: We fix the parameters to a 70-degree field of view with a depth range of 0.01 to 100.
segment.target: We fix the parameters to a 70-degree field of view with a depth range of 0.01 to 100.

segment.source: 4. Creating vertex and pixel shaders with color elements
segment.target: 4. Creating vertex and pixel shaders with color elements

segment.source: In this app, we create more complex vertex and pixel shaders than what we described in the previous tutorial, Creating shaders and drawing primitives.
segment.target: In this app, we create more complex vertex and pixel shaders than what we described in the previous tutorial, Creating shaders and drawing primitives.

segment.source: The app's vertex shader transforms each vertex position into projection space and passes the vertex color through to the pixel shader.
segment.target: The app's vertex shader transforms each vertex position into projection space and passes the vertex color through to the pixel shader.

segment.source: The app's array of D3D11\_INPUT\_ELEMENT\_DESC structures that describe the layout of the vertex shader code has two layout elements: one element defines the vertex position and the other element defines the color.
segment.target: The app's array of D3D11\_INPUT\_ELEMENT\_DESC structures that describe the layout of the vertex shader code has two layout elements: one element defines the vertex position and the other element defines the color.

segment.source: We create vertex, index, and constant buffers to define an orbiting cube.
segment.target: We create vertex, index, and constant buffers to define an orbiting cube.

segment.source: To define an orbiting cube
segment.target: To define an orbiting cube

segment.source: First, we define the cube.
segment.target: First, we define the cube.

segment.source: We assign each vertex a color in addition to a position.
segment.target: We assign each vertex a color in addition to a position.

segment.source: This allows the pixel shader to color each face differently so the face can be distinguished.
segment.target: This allows the pixel shader to color each face differently so the face can be distinguished.

segment.source: Next, we describe the vertex and index buffers (D3D11\_BUFFER\_DESC and D3D11\_SUBRESOURCE\_DATA) using the cube definition.
segment.target: Next, we describe the vertex and index buffers (D3D11\_BUFFER\_DESC and D3D11\_SUBRESOURCE\_DATA) using the cube definition.

segment.source: We call ID3D11Device::CreateBuffer once for each buffer.
segment.target: We call ID3D11Device::CreateBuffer once for each buffer.

segment.source: Next, we create a constant buffer (D3D11\_BUFFER\_DESC) for passing model, view, and projection matrices to the vertex shader.
segment.target: Next, we create a constant buffer (D3D11\_BUFFER\_DESC) for passing model, view, and projection matrices to the vertex shader.

segment.source: We can later use the constant buffer to rotate the cube and apply a perspective projection to it.
segment.target: We can later use the constant buffer to rotate the cube and apply a perspective projection to it.

segment.source: We call ID3D11Device::CreateBuffer to create the constant buffer.
segment.target: We call ID3D11Device::CreateBuffer to create the constant buffer.

segment.source: Next, we specify the view transform that corresponds to a camera position of X = 0, Y = 1, Z = 2.
segment.target: Next, we specify the view transform that corresponds to a camera position of X = 0, Y = 1, Z = 2.

segment.source: Finally, we declare a degree variable that we will use to animate the cube by rotating it every frame.
segment.target: Finally, we declare a degree variable that we will use to animate the cube by rotating it every frame.

segment.source: 5. Rotating and drawing the cube and presenting the rendered image
segment.target: 5. Rotating and drawing the cube and presenting the rendered image

segment.source: We enter an endless loop to continually render and display the scene.
segment.target: We enter an endless loop to continually render and display the scene.

segment.source: We call the rotationY inline function (BasicMath.h) with a rotation amount to set values that will rotate the cube’s model matrix around the Y axis.
segment.target: We call the rotationY inline function (BasicMath.h) with a rotation amount to set values that will rotate the cube’s model matrix around the Y axis.

segment.source: We then call ID3D11DeviceContext::UpdateSubresource to update the constant buffer and rotate the cube model.
segment.target: We then call ID3D11DeviceContext::UpdateSubresource to update the constant buffer and rotate the cube model.

segment.source: We call ID3D11DeviceContext::OMSetRenderTargets to specify the render target as the output target.
segment.target: We call ID3D11DeviceContext::OMSetRenderTargets to specify the render target as the output target.

segment.source: In this OMSetRenderTargets call, we pass the depth-stencil view.
segment.target: In this OMSetRenderTargets call, we pass the depth-stencil view.

segment.source: We call ID3D11DeviceContext::ClearRenderTargetView to clear the render target to a solid blue color and call ID3D11DeviceContext::ClearDepthStencilView to clear the depth buffer.
segment.target: We call ID3D11DeviceContext::ClearRenderTargetView to clear the render target to a solid blue color and call ID3D11DeviceContext::ClearDepthStencilView to clear the depth buffer.

segment.source: In the endless loop, we also draw the cube on the blue surface.
segment.target: In the endless loop, we also draw the cube on the blue surface.

segment.source: To draw the cube
segment.target: To draw the cube

segment.source: First, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetInputLayout to describe how vertex buffer data is streamed into the input-assembler stage.
segment.target: First, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetInputLayout to describe how vertex buffer data is streamed into the input-assembler stage.

segment.source: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetVertexBuffers and ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetIndexBuffer to bind the vertex and index buffers to the input-assembler stage.
segment.target: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetVertexBuffers and ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetIndexBuffer to bind the vertex and index buffers to the input-assembler stage.

segment.source: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetPrimitiveTopology with the D3D11\_PRIMITIVE\_TOPOLOGY\_TRIANGLESTRIP value to specify for the input-assembler stage to interpret the vertex data as a triangle strip.
segment.target: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::IASetPrimitiveTopology with the D3D11\_PRIMITIVE\_TOPOLOGY\_TRIANGLESTRIP value to specify for the input-assembler stage to interpret the vertex data as a triangle strip.

segment.source: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::VSSetShader to initialize the vertex shader stage with the vertex shader code and ID3D11DeviceContext::PSSetShader to initialize the pixel shader stage with the pixel shader code.
segment.target: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::VSSetShader to initialize the vertex shader stage with the vertex shader code and ID3D11DeviceContext::PSSetShader to initialize the pixel shader stage with the pixel shader code.

segment.source: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::VSSetConstantBuffers to set the constant buffer that is used by the vertex shader pipeline stage.
segment.target: Next, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::VSSetConstantBuffers to set the constant buffer that is used by the vertex shader pipeline stage.

segment.source: Finally, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::DrawIndexed to draw the cube and submit it to the rendering pipeline.
segment.target: Finally, we call ID3D11DeviceContext::DrawIndexed to draw the cube and submit it to the rendering pipeline.

segment.source: We call IDXGISwapChain::Present to present the rendered image to the window.
segment.target: We call IDXGISwapChain::Present to present the rendered image to the window.

segment.source: Summary and next steps
segment.target: Summary and next steps

segment.source: We used depth, perspective, color, and other effects on primitives.
segment.target: We used depth, perspective, color, and other effects on primitives.

segment.source: Next, we apply textures to primitives.
segment.target: Next, we apply textures to primitives.

segment.source: Applying textures to primitives
segment.target: Applying textures to primitives
